At 19:12 13/01/2005, you wrote:

>Hi Mattias and Everyone,
>
>I joined the list several months ago and experimented a bit with JNEAT.
>I too have an interest in using NEAT to develop a trading system, or at
>least a very special indicator.
>
>Shortly after I discovered NEAT I also realized my search for
>appropriate inputs was a bit like flailing around in the dark.

Hi,
         With respect to the problem of too many potential inputs.  How 
about something like:

- lots and lots of inputs, all normalised
- one weight on each input
- before running each individual, run through the input weights and zero 
all except the highest N

         This way, only the N most regarded inputs are used by any 
individual, but the population as a whole can explore the whole input 
space.  Speciation can allow groups which use different inputs to 
compete.  Rare cross-species crosses can try to merge the use of different 
sets of inputs.  Because the "circuitry" for every input is always present, 
even when not in use, the system has a memory of how it used to use it, for 
when it comes back, etc etc.

         You might want to scan the network for neurones made inert by the 
zeroed weights, just to reduce the CPU...

         Ian Badcoe
